    Dealing first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement -

    Head 0103 -

    Mr Tang See Chim (Choa Chu Kang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0103 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 3002.

    Sir, this is in regard to the production of Hansard. I wish to know why the sum is reduced to $4,100, when last year's allocation was $16,000. I wonder whether this drastic reduction will affect its efficiency. At present, I must say that the production of Hansard is very efficient and I can give an example to this House.

    During the Budget sitting on 5th December, the Finance Minister ended his Budget Speech sometime, I think, at 4.30 p.m. The next morning at 9.30 the first copy of his speech was ready for the use of Members of this House. I think this is a tribute to the efficiency of the Reporting and Editing Section, and I would like to know why this reduction is made, and also the possible consequences of such a reduction. Would it not lead to inefficiency in the production of Hansard in the future?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, this vote does not refer to the production of Hansard itself but is a vote from which remuneration is paid to part-time staff to assist the Parliamentary Reporters in the overnight production of the first copy. From our experience of the sittings last year, we found that the vote was excessive, as it was not necessary, when the House was not in continuous session, to have copies produced that very same night for Members to have them the following day. Therefore, the vote has been estimated at $4,100 for the following year. It is not the cost of production of Hansard. This is for part-time remuneration paid to people who assist the Parliamentary Reporters in overnight work when the House is in continuous session.

    Sir, since the former Member for Joo Chiat (Dr Fong Kim Heng), who was the Deputy Speaker of this Parliament, resigned, the post of Deputy Speaker has been left vacant. Under subhead 1002 there is still a vote for Deputy Speaker. I wonder whether this House would like to elect a new Deputy Speaker to fill the vacancy. If there is no suitable candidate to fill it, perhaps we can elect a person from outside this Parliament as Deputy Speaker. I hope the Minister concerned can give a satisfactory reply.

    Mr Tang See Chim: I am not moving, Sir.

    The Prime Minister: This vote stands and has stood in every Budget estimate over the last eight years, and at an appropriate time, when there is an obvious choice for the post of Deputy Speaker, the choice will be made. One of the cardinal principles upon which we must exercise the authority which is vested in us by popular vote, is that it should not be exercised just because there is a vote to be spent. Unless duties require the appointment to be made, and there is a person obviously qualified not only in the opinion of the Members of this Parliament but, even more important, in the opinion of the public outside who are watching us, no appointment will be made.

    The last appointment to the office of Deputy Speaker was you, Sir, and I am quite sure that in the next Parliament, which must be elected within three months after the 21st of September, 1968, there will be enough talent amongst the Back-benchers. As Members know, no person who is a Minister or holds

Column: 630

any other office of profit, namely, a Parliamentary Secretary or any other such position, can be Speaker or Deputy Speaker. I am quite optimistic that we will be able to justify an appointment to this high office in the not too distant future.

    Head 0104 -

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0104 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (2) of subhead 2004.

    Sir, holders of scholarships and bursaries are lucky to receive these awards. I believe they include pocket expenses and expenses for books. I wonder why there is a vote for Entertainment Expenses. Can the Minister concerned please explain?

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, in December 1963, at the suggestion of the Chairman of the Public Service Commission, I held a dinner for 132 scholars who had completed their studies abroad on scholarships of various kinds. The purpose was not just to entertain them and to congratulate them on having graduated, but more important, to gather them together in a congenial atmosphere and use the occasion to underline the role for which they were groomed to play. The reason why we have taken the trouble to acquire these scholarships -sometimes from foreign missions and donor foundations -is to give them the kind of training in order that they will fulfil their duties to the community of which they form a part.

    Having been successful with the first function, we held a second one -a buffet dinner -on 23rd April, 1966,

Column: 631

where we had 370 scholars and representatives of foreign missions who had given these scholarships. The purpose was to express our appreciation to these foreign mission representatives for having given the scholarships to our students for training purposes. Similarly a dinner was held on the 1st of July last year. After three successful occasions, Sir, I think it is time that the procedure should be formalised in a vote in the Budget for this purpose.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, will this be a tradition every year?

    The Prime Minister: I am unable to predict what my successors in office will do. But in so far as we are concerned, we are satisfied that such a function does serve a purpose. It does bring home to these scholars in a psychologically meaningful way the fact that they owe something to the community that has gone out of its way to organise itself to train them, educate them and get scholarships for them, and therefore it expects them to give something back to the community. The $3,000 in the vote is hardly more than the first month's salary of probably four or five of these students. I think it is worth the effort that is put in. It is not so much the money; but it takes a lot of effort. And Ministers and others who have to attend these functions so frequently consider this a duty and not a pleasure.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

2.45 p.m.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0104 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2005.

    Sir, much importance has been stressed on industrial development not only

Column: 632

to promote industrial growth but also to maintain the survival of our economy. I note that the sum of $21,600 will be allocated for the "Industrial Development Scholarships Scheme" next year as against $49,200 this year. Perhaps the Prime Minister would care to elaborate on this. Sir, such scholarships will definitely help the industrial development of our young Republic. In this connection, I shall be grateful if the Prime Minister will state the number of scholarships that will be available as against the number this year.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the reason for the estimate being reduced to about 40 per cent of what it was the previous year is that from our experience last year we discovered, partly through the resourcefulness of the Public Service Commission, that quite a number of donor countries were able to provide us with facilities for industrial training. For instance, last year the Belgian Government gave 20 industrial scholarships, and similar awards were made available in France, the United States, Japan, Germany, the United Kingdom and several other countries. This being so, the amount required to be paid out of the Budget itself is reduced by the amount which was extended in scholarship aid. So we are not unoptimistic that next year these donor countries, with whom we maintain amicable and, we hope, mutually beneficial relationships, will find it in their interest as well as ours to continue to offer industrial training facilities.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Prime Minister for his reply and, on that note, may I beg leave to withdraw my amendment?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0104 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2009*.
* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Yeah Ghim Seng.


    Sir, I can well remember that the subject of the President's scholarships was raised by my colleague, the hon.

Column: 633

Member for Aljunied, in this Chamber on the 15th of this month last year. The Prime Minister in his reply stated that the recipients -I quote from Hansard, Volume 25, No. 10, column 694:

    '...are people who have won signal distinction for themselves to merit special privileges for further education.' The Prime Minister further stressed, in the same column, Sir, and I quote:

    '...it is hoped to continue a supply of men not only well qualified and competent in their own fields of study but with all the social and other graces which make for the difficult-to-define quality called leadership.' Sir, I can imagine the fierce and keen competition by our brilliant students to win such a high honour. In this respect, Sir, I shall be grateful if the Prime Minister will explain the reduction made in the vote next year, that is, from $143,000 this year to $110,000 next year. Also, will he inform this House of the number of recipients of the President's scholarships this year and the likely number next year?

    Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng (Joo Chiat): Mr Speaker, Sir, we pride ourselves in this country on our President's scholars, as they represent the cream of our schools and thus of our youths. These scholars are sent abroad as junior ambassadors and are therefore sent with a lot of fanfare and with the country's blessings. For the past few years, Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of school children enrolling in schools must have increased tremendously and, therefore, I would have expected a wider selection of first-class pupils for the coveted and signal honour of being President's scholars. At least, Sir, one would have expected the number of such scholarships to remain the same annually. Yet I see that the 1968 vote has been cut from the 1967 vote of $143,000 to $110,000. Surely, the Public Service Commission or the Prime Minister cannot tell this House that our pupils are deteriorating in their mental capacity. If not, why has there been such a drastic cut in the President's Scholarships vote? Surely such a cut is not very encouraging to our students

Column: 634

in the schools because they have been trying their best to gain the honour of being the President's scholars. So, Mr Speaker, Sir, I hope the Prime Minister will reconsider the estimated amount for the vote so that the number of President's scholars for 1968 will remain at least the same as for 1967.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I assure both the Members who have raised this problem that, far from the number of potential talented young men and women reducing in numbers as the years go by, they have, in fact, shown a capacity not only to win the President's scholarships, but also to take a few other scholarships by the way; and the President's scholar is often a person who holds at least one other scholarship. The President's scholarship is given on the basis of merit, not on the basis of need, and inevitably the boy who wins it also gets some other scholarship. When he does that, then, if he is studying abroad, whether it is in the United Kingdom, Australia or Canada, he does not get the full scholarship but he gets an allowance of œ250, because otherwise we will ruin him by giving him too much money.

    I have also told Members of the House that last year there were seven President's scholars; three of them decided to study in the University of Singapore, one at the Polytechnic, one in Britain, one in Australia, and one in Canada. They had a free choice of where to go for higher studies. Four out of seven chose to study here. That has also saved us the cost of the passages going overseas. I am quite sure that next year, as in the case of this year, these scholars will also be able to win other awards whilst being the President's scholars.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, one last question. According to the Hansard of 15th December, 1966, there were nine winners for these scholarships last year, but this year there are only seven. I wonder why.

    The Prime Minister: I am afraid I must assume that the Public Service Commission puts a very high standard

Column: 635

for the attainment of the status of a President's scholar, and if there are not more than seven such scholars, then not more than seven President's scholarships are awarded. It is a very proper way of maintaining standards. It does not mean that just because you have in the Budget Estimates ten posts for Political Secretaries, therefore, we appoint ten Political Secretaries. We do not, as Members well know. We appoint Political Secretaries as and when they are found necessary and as and when there are suitable candidates. I am quite sure the same principles must have applied in the Public Service Commission in not awarding more than seven President's scholarships for this year. They must vary from year to year. Sometimes you have a bumper harvest. In some particular year the wine is of special vintage.

    Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng: Is it customary to give a scholar more than one scholarship? Would it not be better to distribute the scholarships around so that more students will benefit?

    The Prime Minister: When we instituted the President's Scholarships, we had in mind what used to prevail for many years before the war when the British awarded the Queen's scholarships which were awarded purely on the basis of merit. It does not matter whether the President's scholars need the money or whether they deserve it or do not deserve it for purely financial or social reasons, as long as they have the capacity, the excellence, to merit the award. If they can win other scholarships, then they will not get the full award; but they will get when they go abroad a scholarship allowance of œ50 Sterling per annum in addition to the allowances they have obtained under the other awards, instead of the full cost being borne by Government. It is quite common. The Member for Joo Chiat will know that if he turns up the preface of many of his scholarly journals or books, even in his particular field of surgery, there is great pride in referring to the fact that the man was

Column: 636

holding three different scholarships at the time when he was an under-graduate in some college or university. And often because they are holding three different scholarships for which they have competed and won on merit, they do not get in each case the full award of each scholarship. The award is then given to somebody else on the basis of need, that he was not really good enough to get it but because he was fortunate that the man who was good enough to win it had already got another one. He gets the consolation prize.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, I am satisfied with the answers given by the Prime Minister and I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0104 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2012.

    The subject of Malaya Hall -I think it is now called Malaysia Hall -is dear to my heart and I was interested to find that the sum allocated this year was doubled to $300,000. I sought explanation in Appendix H which says that Government's contribution is "shared in proportion of students from each territory including Sabah and Sarawak." I wonder whether the Prime Minister can inform this House whether the number of our students using Malaysia Hall has, in fact, doubled in the course of the year. I was in Malaysia Hall sometime at the beginning of this year and there was no evidence of that.

    The Prime Minister: First, may I explain that we paid one-third of the capital cost of acquiring the premises of Malaysia Hall. In other words, in equity we own one of the three fairly substantial houses which were joined together to form Malaysia Hall. This is the first point we want to establish, that we own one-third of the capital. With the accretion of Sabah and

Column: 637

Sarawak, we deem that our share of the running expenses should be reduced, but we still nevertheless own one-third of the capital. We were one-third of the student population without including Sabah and Sarawak. With Sabah and Sarawak we consider ourselves one-fourth. So we held up payments for the years 1965 to 1966 and 1966 to 1967 pending clarification in sorting out the proportions. Now it has been agreed that if we take Singapore and Malaysia together, not Singapore and just Malaya, we will pay one-quarter. So this is for two years' payment. Arrears have to be paid up. But in making this point I want to make it quite clear that this does not mean we own one-quarter of Malaysia Hall. We still own one of the three houses in Malaysia Hall. It so happened that we bought three houses and we paid one-third. We are happy to have all the students together even though we are now separate and different countries. But if people should ever consider our students should be excluded, then we will not be collecting one-fourth of three houses but we will be collecting one-third of three houses, which is exactly one house.

    Mr Tang See Chim: I wish to withdraw the amendment, Sir.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 0104 be reduced by $l00*.
* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Tang See Chim.


    Sir, as I understand it, the function of the Public Service Commission is to regulate impartially the public service. This Commission works on an independent basis with wide powers to appoint and promote persons in the public service.

    The Chairman: Mr Sim, may I just here warn you that we are five minutes short of guillotine time under this Head?

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: Yes, Sir. Not forgetting that the Commission has also powers to dismiss any public servant.

Column: 638

What I wish to raise in this House today is as a result of rumours being spread about the Public Service Commission. These rumours no doubt are untrue but they have become quite persistent and are damaging to the good name of the Public Service Commission, although I do not believe them.

    The Prime Minister: Then do not repeat them.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: I am troubled by these rumours and that is why I hope that by bringing up this matter, these unfounded rumours will be killed once and for all. The talk in the town is that some people are unhappy with the Public Service Commission and that it is prejudiced and biased in selecting candidates for appointments and promotions, to the extent of saying that the Public Service Commission is pro-Chinese. Sir, I do not think this is so.

    The Prime Minister: You should not repeat rumours if you do not believe them.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: Sir, I think the Public Service Commission is doing excellent work. I do hope that when the new Constitution is presented to Parliament, there will be provision for increasing the membership to the Commission so that it will be possible to give a more balanced and multi-racial composition. However, Sir, in making this suggestion I am not casting any aspersions on the office of the Chairman nor on any of the members of the Public Service Commission. As I have pointed out, they are doing excellent work.     Hon. Members have had occasion to hear of matters pertaining to certain resignations being brought up in this House and no doubt satisfactory explanations have been given.

    The Chairman: Mr Sim, if you want an answer, I am afraid you will have to stop now.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: Sir, I hope the Prime Minister will seriously consider my suggestion.

Column: 639



    Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, in view of the shortage of time, I just want to bring up one matter and that is the non-recognition by the Public Service Commission of certain American degrees. Will the Prime Minister enlighten us?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I am very disturbed that the Member for Changi, who has been a very politically active and alive individual with the P.A.P, for the last 13 years since its inception, should have forgotten the fundamental principle that the best way to spread a rumour is to repeat it, and the worst place to repeat it is in a place which has got the authority which will carry it over the radio, into the newspapers and on television. I do not know if he has been watching how other people use their radio and television stations. I heard with consternation how some Ministers in some other countries in the world visited riot areas and then told of their experiences. Their saying these things at the wrong time and giving wider credence and publicity to it caused further disorders to take place. I would have thought that the simple and obvious axiom -not to give the lie more credence by repeating it -would have been the one decisive factor in not having raised this matter at all.

    There are five members of the P.S.C. -three are Chinese, one is an Indian and one is a Malay. There are 80 per cent Chinese citizens, 7.6 per cent Malay citizens, and about 7.2 per cent Indian citizens. It is impossible to have the Public Service Commission enlarged to a number which will include proportional representation from each community. There will be the Eurasians, the Ceylonese, the Burmese, the Malays of Indonesian descent, the Malays of Malaysian descent, and so on. I would have thought that the surest way in which a matter such as this can be disposed of is by moral rectitude, that

Column: 640

is, those people who work and get promoted in the public service get promoted on the basis of merit.

    I have no time to reply to the other question about recognition of American degrees. It is a very wide and complicated subject and neither the Member for Choa Chu Kang nor I am all that familiar with American institutions. They are very numerous and very varied in the quality of the products to whom they give degrees.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: Sir, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Head 0105 -

    Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0105 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1004.

    Sir, in moving the amendment to the vote for subhead 1004, I also wish to move *amendments (2) and (3) , because they are all inter-related. With your permission, I shall do that together.

    The Chairman: Please move your first amendment alone, Mr Tang, but you may, in your comments, range over all three subheads.

    In last year's debate in Committee of Supply, I raised the question of State Counsel or Legal Officers being kept at one post for a considerable length of time, so much so that when they came up for promotion before the Legal Service Commission, they were asked what experience they had got. Of course, they had none because they were kept

Column: 641

in that one post for a long time, a state of affairs to which they themselves did not agree. I was then assured by the Acting Minister for Law -it was the Minister for Health then replying on behalf of the Minister for Law and National Development -who said this state of affairs would be looked into and he assured the House that it would not be continued. With your permission, Sir, may I quote from Hansard - The Chairman: Mr Tang, in view of our time-table, quotation from Hansard is perhaps not necessary. I am sure the Minister would have read that particular passage in Hansard before he came here for discussion of your amendment to this subhead.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Unfortunately, such a state of affairs appears to persist and I would like an explanation and an assurance from the Minister that it would be remedied.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the matters raised by the Member for Choa Chu Kang are wholly within the province, as it were, of the Legal Service Commission. This Commission is, by the provisions of the Constitution, independent of the Government. But there are six members of the Legal Service Commission.

3.15 p.m.

    It consists of the Chief Justice as Chairman, a Judge, the Chairman of the Public Service Commission and two other members of the Public Service Commission, together with the Attorney-General. I can only speak on behalf of one member, and that is the Attorney-General. He assures me that law graduates fresh from the University who are appointed to the Bench straightaway are normally given an opportunity to broaden their field of experience long before their period of probation expires, so that by the time they come up for confirmation or entry into the legal service proper, they would, in the majority of cases, have held appointments in his Chambers as well as in the Courts.

Column: 642



    The Chairman: Mr Barker, I am afraid you must shorten your remarks.

    Mr Barker: But shortly, Sir, it is the Legal Service Commission which is responsible for the transfers, appointments as well as confirmation of all legal officers. These officers are not my men, and the members of the Commission will know the reasons why a certain officer is kept either in the Courts or in the Chambers or transferred from one Court to another. I am afraid I have no jurisdiction over the matter.

    Head 0107 -

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0107 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1010.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid the Minister for Law has anticipated part of my argument in his reply to my earlier amendment regarding newly qualified persons being appointed to the Bench. However, my reason against this is that this is not a very good practice, because a newly qualified person should do a stint in the A.G.'s Chambers first rather than being appointed to the Bench straightaway. Also a newly qualified person appointed to the Bench is likely to be transferred at one time or another to the Attorney-General's Chambers where his superior is someone who had appeared before him when he was on the Bench. This is an invidious position to place a newly qualified person as a magistrate and it is unfair to him. This could result in a perversion of the course of justice.

    Mr P. Selvadurai (Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may make a point quickly on the question of the appointment of magistrates to the Bench straight from the university. Quite often, many of our magistrates today are

Column: 643

appointed to the Bench immediately after getting their degrees in the university here or after returning from the United Kingdom with their Bar qualifications. This is a matter which was dis. cussed at great length in this very House on 16th December, 1957, when the Prime Minister himself made the point that it is always difficult to have inexperienced magistrates listening to cases dealing with involved facts as well as involved laws. The position today seems to be similar to that which obtained in 1957 and we do not seem to have progressed.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I was really interested in what the Minister said about the Public Service Commission. I get the impression that the malaise really rests in the way in which the Public Service Commission itself is constituted. Section 6 (4) (f) of the Republic of Singapore Independence Act, 1965, reads:
